readings.description: Uses game theory & incentives, but very reflective and critical; firmly about big macro political-economy questions.
Middle on culture vs incentives: emphasizes preferences, norms and payoffs; links micro behavior to big outcomes.

readings.reading: Bowles – Social Institutions and Institutional Design
readings.description: Slightly more on the culture/norms side than Prologue; still institutional design, but with strong emphasis on social norms & fairness.
Very incentives/enforcement focused (what happens when state enforcement is weak); applied to broader, semi-macro settings.

readings.reading: Roine – Why Isn't the Whole World Rich?
readings.description: Strong institutional + historical + inequality focus; much more about structural macro differences than micro norms.

readings.reading: Greif – Institutions and the Path to the Modern Economy (2006)
readings.description: Balanced: rules + beliefs + organizations (so middle-ish on X); spans from medieval trade micro to long-run European macro.

readings.reading: Greif – Reputation & Coalitions in Medieval Trade (1989, Maghribi)
readings.description: Still a blend of beliefs and incentives (so central-ish on X), but clearly more micro: specific trader coalition and repeated-game structure.

readings.reading: Mokyr – Cultural Entrepreneurs and the Origins of Modern Economic Growth (2013)
readings.description: Heavy on culture, ideas, beliefs, pro-innovation attitudes; macro history of growth and the IR.
Strong focus on credible commitment, constraints on rulers, capital markets, and national growth after the Glorious Revolution.

readings.reading: Acemoglu, Johnson & Robinson – Institutions as the Fundamental Cause (2005)
readings.description: As far toward 'power & incentives & macro' as you can go: institutions = political power + distribution + colonial history.

readings.reading: Acemoglu & Robinson – Political Losers as a Barrier (2000)
readings.description: Same underlying view: elites block change; very power/conflict-oriented; slightly less broad than the 2005 handbook piece.

readings.reading: Ostrom – Collective Action and Evolution of Social Norms (2000)
readings.description: Norms/reciprocity/self-governance (so lower on X); mainly groups & communities, experiments & local commons (so lower on Y).
Mix of growth-through-incentives (Aghion–Howitt creative destruction) and cultural/scientific preconditions (Mokyr); clearly macro frontier growth.
